poem_title: FAIRY TALE IN THE Ancient ENGLISH Style.
author: Thomas Parnell

lines.line_text: Endow'd with Courage, Sense and Truth,

stanzas.stanza_text:
IN  Isle and  days,
When Midnight  daunc'd the Maze,
Liv'd  of the Green;
I wis, a gentle Youth,
Endow'd with Courage, Sense and Truth,
Tho' badly Shap'd he been.

lines.line_text: His Mountain Back mote well be said
To measure heigth against his Head,
Yet spite of all that Nature did
To make his uncouth Form forbid,

stanzas.stanza_text:
His Mountain Back mote well be said
To measure heigth against his Head,
And lift it self above:
Yet spite of all that Nature did
To make his uncouth Form forbid,
This Creature dar'd to love.

lines.line_text: He felt the Charms of  Eyes,
Nor wanted Hope to gain the Prize,
But one Sir  dress'd with Art,
And, if a Shape cou'd win a Heart,
He had a Shape to win.

stanzas.stanza_text:
He felt the Charms of  Eyes,
Nor wanted Hope to gain the Prize,
Cou'd Ladies look within;
But one Sir  dress'd with Art,
And, if a Shape cou'd win a Heart,
He had a Shape to win.

(if right I read my Song)
With slighted Passion pac'd along
All in the Moony Light:
'Twas near an old enchaunted Court,
Where sportive  made Resort
To revel out the Night.

lines.line_text: His Heart was drear, his Hope was cross'd,
'Twas late, 'twas farr, the Path was lost
With weary Steps he quits the Shades,
Resolv'd the darkling Dome he treads,

stanzas.stanza_text:
His Heart was drear, his Hope was cross'd,
'Twas late, 'twas farr, the Path was lost
That reach'd the Neighbour-Town;
With weary Steps he quits the Shades,
Resolv'd the darkling Dome he treads,
And drops his Limbs adown.

lines.line_text: But scant he lays him on the Floor,
When hollow Winds remove the Door,
And (well I ween to count aright)
At once an hundred Tapers light

stanzas.stanza_text:
But scant he lays him on the Floor,
When hollow Winds remove the Door,
A trembling rocks the Ground:
And (well I ween to count aright)
At once an hundred Tapers light
On all the Walls around.

lines.line_text: Now sounding Tongues assail his Ear,
And from the Corner where he lay
He sees a Train profusely gay

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now sounding Tongues assail his Ear,
Now sounding Feet approachen near,
And now the Sounds encrease:
And from the Corner where he lay
He sees a Train profusely gay
Come pranckling o'er the Place.

lines.line_text: Was dight a Masquing half so neat,
The Country lent the sweet Perfumes,
The Sea the Pearl, the Sky the Plumes,

stanzas.stanza_text:
But (trust me ) never yet
Was dight a Masquing half so neat,
Or half so rich before;
The Country lent the sweet Perfumes,
The Sea the Pearl, the Sky the Plumes,
The Town its silken Store.

lines.line_text: Now whilst he gaz'd, a  drest
In flaunting Robes above the rest,
Whose Sighs infect the balmy Wind,

stanzas.stanza_text:
Now whilst he gaz'd, a  drest
In flaunting Robes above the rest,
With awfull Accent cry'd;
What  of a wretched Mind,
Whose Sighs infect the balmy Wind,
Has here presum'd to hide?

lines.line_text: At this the  whose vent'rous Soul
'Nor have I Cause of Dreed, he said,
' Who view by no Presumption led

stanzas.stanza_text:
At this the  whose vent'rous Soul
No Fears of  Art controul,
Advanc'd in open sight;
'Nor have I Cause of Dreed, he said,
' Who view by no Presumption led
'Your Revels of the Night.

lines.line_text: 'Twas Grief, for Scorn of faithful Love,
Who dare to tell us true.

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Twas Grief, for Scorn of faithful Love,
'Which made my Steps unweeting, rove
' Amid the nightly Dew.
'Tis well, the  crys again,
We  never injure Men
Who dare to tell us true.

lines.line_text: Be mine the Task, or e'er we part,
Now take the Pleasure of thy Chaunce;
Whilst I with  my part'ner daunce,
He spoke, and all a sudden there
Light Musick floats in wanton Air;

stanzas.stanza_text:
He spoke, and all a sudden there
Light Musick floats in wanton Air;
The  leads the
The rest their  Partners found,
And  trimly tript the Ground
With  of the Green.

lines.line_text: The Dauncing past, the Board was laid,
And siker such a Feast was made
The Glasses with a Wish come nigh,

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Dauncing past, the Board was laid,
And siker such a Feast was made
As Heart and Lip desire;
Withouten Hands the Dishes fly,
The Glasses with a Wish come nigh,
And with a Wish retire.

lines.line_text: Full ev'ry deal they laugh and sing,
Some wind and tumble like an Ape,

stanzas.stanza_text:
But now to please the
Full ev'ry deal they laugh and sing,
And antick Feats devise;
Some wind and tumble like an Ape,
And other-some transmute their Shape
In  wond'ring Eyes.

lines.line_text: And full against the Beam he flung,
Where by the Back the  he hung

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Till one at last that  hight,
(Renown'd for pinching Maids by Night)
Has hent him up aloof;
And full against the Beam he flung,
Where by the Back the  he hung
To spraul unneath the Roof.

lines.line_text: From thence, "Reverse my Charm, he crys,
" And let it fairely now suffice

stanzas.stanza_text:
From thence, "Reverse my Charm, he crys,
" And let it fairely now suffice
"The Gambol has been shown.
But  answers with a Smile,
Content thee  for a while,
The Vantage is thine own.

lines.line_text: They smelt the fresh Approach of Day,
And heard a Cock to crow;
The whirling Wind that bore the Crowd
Has clap'd the Door, and whistled loud,
To warn them all to go.
Then screaming all at once they fly,
And all at once the Tapers dy;
Forlorn his State, and dark the Place,
Was never Wight in sike a Case
Full Jolly Creature home he goes,
He feels his Back the less;
His honest Tongue and steady Mind
Han rid him of the Lump behind

stanzas.stanza_text:
But soon as Dan  rose,
Full Jolly Creature home he goes,
He feels his Back the less;
His honest Tongue and steady Mind
Han rid him of the Lump behind
Which made him want Success.

lines.line_text: He seems a dauncing as he walks,
Endow'd with Courage, Sense and Truth,

stanzas.stanza_text:
With lusty livelyhed he talks,
He seems a dauncing as he walks,
His Story soon took wind;
And beautious  sees the Youth,
Endow'd with Courage, Sense and Truth,
Without a Bunch behind.

lines.line_text: At close of Eve he leaves his home,
And wends to find the ruin'd Dome

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Story told, Sir  mov'd,
(The Youth of  erst approv'd)
To see the Revel Scene:
At close of Eve he leaves his home,
And wends to find the ruin'd Dome
All on the gloomy Plain.

lines.line_text: As there he bides, it so befell,
The Wind came rustling down a Dell,
Up spring the Tapers as before,

stanzas.stanza_text:
As there he bides, it so befell,
The Wind came rustling down a Dell,
A shaking seiz'd the Wall:
Up spring the Tapers as before,
The  bragly foot the Floor,
And Musick fills the Hall.

But  sorely sunk with woe
Sir  sees the  show,
His Spirits in him dy:
When  crys, 'a  is near,
' A mortall Passion, cleeped Fear,
'Hangs flagging in the Sky.

lines.line_text: In Accents fault'ring ay for Ruth
For als he been a mister Wight
Betray'd by wand'ring in the Night
'Ah Losell Vile, at once they roar!
' Now has thy Kestrell Courage fell;
' Are free to work thee Woe.

stanzas.stanza_text:
'Ah Losell Vile, at once they roar!
' And little skill'd of  lore,
'Thy Cause to come we know:
' Now has thy Kestrell Courage fell;
'And  since a Ly you tell,
' Are free to work thee Woe.

lines.line_text: To trail the Swains among the Mire,
There like a Tortoise in a Shop

stanzas.stanza_text:
Then  who bears the  Fire
To trail the Swains among the Mire,
The Caitive upward flung;
There like a Tortoise in a Shop
He dangled from the Chamber-top,
Where whilome  hung.

lines.line_text: Deffly they frisk it o'er the Place,
They sit, they drink, and eat;
The time with frolick Mirth beguile,
And poor Sir  hangs the while

stanzas.stanza_text:
The Revel now proceeds apace,
Deffly they frisk it o'er the Place,
They sit, they drink, and eat;
The time with frolick Mirth beguile,
And poor Sir  hangs the while
'Till all the Rout retreat.

lines.line_text: By this the Starrs began to wink,
They skriek, they fly, the Tapers sink,
With strong Enchantment bound a Glade

stanzas.stanza_text:
By this the Starrs began to wink,
They skriek, they fly, the Tapers sink,
And down ydrops the
For never Spell by  laid
With strong Enchantment bound a Glade
Beyond the length of Night.

lines.line_text: Chill, dark, alone, adreed, he lay,
Till up the Welkin rose the Day,
Then deem'd the Dole was o'er:
But wot ye well his harder Lot?
His seely Back the  has got

stanzas.stanza_text:
Chill, dark, alone, adreed, he lay,
Till up the Welkin rose the Day,
Then deem'd the Dole was o'er:
But wot ye well his harder Lot?
His seely Back the  has got
Which  lost afore.

lines.line_text: She softly strok'd my youngling Head,
And when the Tale was done,
'Thus some are born, my Son (she cries)

stanzas.stanza_text:
This Tale a  ared;
She softly strok'd my youngling Head,
And when the Tale was done,
'Thus some are born, my Son (she cries)
' With base Impediments to rise,
'And some are born with none.

lines.line_text: ' To what the Fav'rite Fools of Chance
'Virtue can gain the Odds of Fate,
' And from it self shake off the Weight

stanzas.stanza_text:
'But Virtue can it self advance
' To what the Fav'rite Fools of Chance
' By Fortune seem'd design'd;
'Virtue can gain the Odds of Fate,
' And from it self shake off the Weight
'Upon th' unworthy
